reasoning: The critique targets one sub-branch in a long list of ways a seemingly good future could still go morally wrong: extending full political rights (incl. voting) to digital beings might lead to governance dominated by non-human values. Pointing out Sybil-attack dynamics (fake/cheap-to-create ‘citizens’ capturing governance) is relevant and mostly correct as an additional failure mode, but it doesn’t substantially undermine the essay’s core thesis (‘no easy eutopia’/future value fragility) and is largely compatible with it—indeed it arguably reinforces “fragility” rather than refutes it. It also somewhat misreads the essay’s framing: the essay is presenting multiple distinct moral-catastrophe pathways, not offering “AI voting rights” as a balanced/symmetric policy risk assessment; adding an adversarial-security angle doesn’t show the original risk was wrongly characterized, only incomplete. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Digital voting rights create civilizational-scale Sybil attack vulnerabilities
